status_notes: Case Resolved. The City of Boston does control Boston Public Schools, so they may be closed by direction of Mayor Walsh and Superintendent Chang.  The city does not have this authority over private daycare centers.  Governor Baker and Mayor Walsh can request that private sector employers allow non-essential workers to stay home, but they can only actually order this for state and city workers.  Most citizens have to abide by the wishes of their own employers and are likely to have to report to work; thus requiring private daycare services.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) agrees that the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to Verizon. Since there is a moratorium on concrete/brick  work until April 1st, the patch will have to stay as is. Verizon has been notified to remove the bricks and  house them in a safe place  and restore the sidewalk to brick in the Spring of 2017. We also told them to remove the sign. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. The CIU inspector will inspect periodically to make sure that the patch holds up during the winter. If the asphalt patch does not meet our standards Verizon be notified  to come back and re do the patch over. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

But after investigation, I contacted the Church of the Covenant as the closest location to the complainant at 54 Commonwealth Ave. . . After talking to the Parish Administrator and Building Manager, he immediately contacted his trash hauling contractor to see if they can reschedule their pickup for after 7am.  They agreed to do so, but it will take a few days to get that in their operating system and to make sure that their driver pickups after 7am.

status_notes: Case Noted. The citywide default speed limit is 25 mph unless otherwise posted. The Boston Transportation Department has a posted regulatory speed zone of 30 mph on Bennington St east of Route 1A to the Revere City Line, based on previous traffic engineering studies. Bennington St is classified as a major arterial. BTD has recently reviewed traffic data collected in this section of Bennington St, including the prevailing speed and volume of traffic. At this time, they have decided to retain the 30 mph posted speed limit on Bennington Street from Route 1A to the Revere City Line and will continue to monitor in the future.
description: SIXTH REQUEST. Earliest Case number 101001984239. The speed limit signs along the full length of Bennington Street, from Central Square to Beachmont, must be changed as soon as possible. Bennington Street for the past many years, has been a speeding zone for motorists.  In fact there have been multiple pedestrian injuries, as well as deaths, on this road. Please respond immediately.

Re:case # 1995399

In regards to the "illegal" dumping of garbage from those businesses and properties from 466, 470 472 Comm Ave, onto another street (Newbury) a block away, treating our street like a City Dump because of some bright idea from some lazy soul that thought it might be ok if they just went ahead and started to do it?
No public meeting asking the residents of our street if ok?
(((Because it's not ok)))

Hmmm, simple solution
Utilize a parking space (as others do to place their trash for pick up)
If they do not have a parking space available from the property then purchase or rent a parking space in the back alley for trash pick up.
Million dollar properties and to not have proper waste management is ridiculous.
Profit before public safety
Profit before public wellbeing
 
This is an easy fix
Reserve a parking space in the alley behind their property (like others do) to place their trash for pick up (like others in this neighborhood does)
They can afford it obviously

description:
Re case#1995399

What?
What kind of "alternative facts" are these?

Trucks can't get down alley?!

What? Really? Says who?!!!

Trucks come down this alley (between Newbury and Comm Ave on this block) twice a week to service the trash from Newbury and Comm Ave.
Me thinks someone's better judgement is taking a backseat on this one.

We the residents of Newbury don't put "our trash out on this street for pick up.
Why are you basically giving the OK for no legitimate "factual" reason for businesses and resident from another street to "dump and pollute their trash for pick up on our street?!!
That's just crazy talk...
We will not be marginalized because of someone else's laziness to truly fix this issue.
Trash trucks can't fit down the alley?
Since when?
Ridiculous answer
Fix it please
Thank you

description:
Re case #1995145

These barrels and hampers that recently have been put out on our street for pick up of garbage seems highly illegal!!!

These barrels are from residences and businesses that are located on another street a block away!
They are from 466 Commonwealth Ave
As well as 470 Commonwealth Ave and others that see this are encouraged to dump their garbage here also.
None of this seems right.
Was there a public meeting asking the residents of this street if we are ok with businesses and property owners (from another street) to pollute our street with their garbage like this?!
Please have them store their trash and schedule their pickups on from their property, on their street.
Our street is not a public dump for them to place their poorly managed trash out on for pick up.
The residents of Newbury st are not allowed to do this, so why are people from another street entirely, bringing their garbage to our street for dumping and pick up.
Seems ridiculous and wrong.
Please fix this.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our safety issues map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

description:
Thank you!

To all at Bos311
To everyone that works tirelessly day and night to keep our streets clean and safe,
Thank you
Your work is greatly appreciated.
And truly noticed
Thank you
And to Delores, forgive me if I sounded a bit frustrated tonight, I am sorry for that.
I recently had to pay thousands in repairs to my vehicle because of rodents that had been overwhelming our community.
This neighborhood has improved greatly recently because of all the hard work of those at Bos311, The Mayors Office, elected officials and regular citizens feeling the need to fix the problem of the infestation that is all but extinct now Thank God, but there is still work to do.
There has been much more support by others that recognize that properly containing ones refuse is the best deterrent.
Eliminate their food source and they go elsewhere.
So yeah major, very successful strides have been made in the community recently and seeing trash left out nowadays is somewhat frustrating  and counterproductiveto say the least, 
Thank you though for everything

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern about perceived speeding to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our ?safety issues? map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for reaching out. The City of Boston and Commonwealth of Massachusetts does not have any additional regulations in place beyond the standards set by the FAA. If your drone is registered please remember to keep it within your line of sight at all times. Do not fly near other aircraft, or near other people or moving vehicles. For more information you can visit: https://www.boston.gov/departments/parks-and-recreation/recreational-drone-use.
description:

Alternatively I want to use my drone. It is a DJI Mavic pro and it is registered (FA39X7KCXX, California). Is it allowed to use the drone near by this property? I would take some pictures by Saturday, 01-28-2017. Do I need a second registration for MA? Thank you for your response.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Thank  you for your concern.  BTD is aware of the illegal turn at this intersection and resulted of the posting of the right turn restriction sign on Beech facing Leniston St  and the left turn only sign on Leniston St.  BTD will share this issue with the local Boston Police Dept in your area to assist with enforcement. Unfortunately a stop sign for this issue cannot be installed on Beech St  under federal guidelines. The purpose of the Stop Sign is to designate right-of-way to vehicles making conflicting movements. It is not intended, nor shall it be used for the control of speed, traffic calming or to forestall. pedestrian, rear-end or turning movement accidents. Thank you for your understanding.
